title: Question 18
prompt: How do the two stanzas of this poem differ from each other?
description: Click the <u>one best answer</u> to each question.
feedback:
While both stanzas are from the point of view of the mirror, the first stanza describes the mirror’s self-perception. The mirror is silver; it is exact. It reflects things truthfully. It reflects the pink wall on the other side of the room most of the time, and its reflection of the pink wall is broken on and off by faces and darkness. The pronoun “I” appears throughout the stanza. The second stanza, though, describes the woman’s interaction with the mirror. She looks in the mirror, wondering who she really is. She cries and waves her hands. She looks in the mirror each morning. The focus of this stanza is not on the mirror, but on the woman. The pronouns “she” and “her” appear throughout the stanza.


I am silver and exact. I have no preconceptions.
Whatever I see, I swallow immediately.
just as it is, unmisted by love or dislike
I am not cruel, only truthful—
The eye of a little god, four-cornered.
Most of the time I meditate on the opposite wall.
It is pink, with speckles. I have looked at it so long
I think it is a part of my heart. But it flickers.
Faces and darkness separate us over and over.

Now I am a lake. A woman bends over me.
Searching my reaches for what she really is.
Then she turns to those liars, the candles or the moon.
I see her back, and reflect it faithfully
She rewards me with tears and an agitation of hands.
I am important to her. She comes and goes.
Each morning it is her face that replaces the darkness.
In me she has drowned a young girl, and in me an old woman
Rises toward her day after day, like a terrible fish.
